 .H/O [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
   43 yoM with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG & trach; admitted with stable
   tongue lac from biting tongue.  Awaiting mouth guard from occupational
   health. Pt also presents with abdominal distension, although no pain to
   palpation.
   .
   #. TONGUE LACERATION: On talking to the patient
s sister and mother
   further, it sounds like the patient
s tongue biting has been off and on
   for the last week or two since he was on medication
to bring down his
   K
   -- will attempt to get additional records from Radius re: pt
s recent
   behavior and ? hyperkalemia
   -- will check EEG to make sure tongue biting is not seizure activity
   given his h/o anoxic injury
   -- hct at baseline; recheck in am but does not need daily labs if going
   to be in house for some time
   -- T&S
   -- f/u appt with OM surgery per note ([**Hospital 3348**] Clinic [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11173**])
   -- Tylenol for comfort
   .
   #. S/P ANOXIC BRAIN INJURY:
   -- cont trach/vent; requirements stable
   -- [**Name (NI) 5055**] (unclear what on at baseline; INR slightly elevated likely from
   nutrition)
   .
   #. ABD DISTENTION: unclear why he is distended; KUB ordered from Radius
   on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction. Two BMs overnight, with
   improved abd distension.
   -- hold tube feeds for now
   -- check KUB here
 no evidence of obstruction or perforation
   -- add on LFT
s and lipase given history of pancreatitis in recent past
   (lipase 800 in [**Month (only) 594**])
   -- if all normal, will optimize bowel regimen.
   .
   #. CHF: Pt appears volume up on exam, with sig peripheral edema (off
   baseline, per pt
s family), JVD difficult to assess.
   -- CXR to assess vol status
 consider more aggressive diuresis if
   evidence of fluid overload
 none seen
   -- changed home PO dose lasix to IV (home dose is 20 mg; will give 10
   mg IV given c/f gut edema and not absorbing PO
   -- holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K
   .
   #. HYPERLIPIDEMIA, h/o STEMI:
   -- cont home regimen of ASA, carvedolol, lisinopril, lipitor
   .
   #. GERD: cont home omeprazole 40 mg QD
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- humalog SSI
   .
   #. FEN:
   -- cont home MVI, B1, folic acid
   -- per pt care referral form, on replete with fiber at 70 cc/hr, free
   water flushes 200 ml Q6 hours --> NPO for now given abd distention
   .
   #. ACCESS: one PIV on right
   .
   #. PPX: -- [**Month (only) 5055**], bowel regimen, home omeprazole
   .
   #. CODE: FULL
   .
   #. ICU consent: signed and in chart
   .
   #. DISPO: possibly back to rehab after mouth guard
   -- will discuss case in AM  with case management in terms of placement,
   as family seems frustrated with current care at Radius

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with anoxic brain injury, chronic respiratory failure with a tracheostomy in place, and a tongue laceration. He is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has been experiencing abdominal distension. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 103/70 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination reveals that he is trached and on vent, sleeping and easily arousable, but non-verbal and does not follow commands. He has a tongue laceration and is experiencing abdominal distension, which is not accompanied by pain to palpation.

The patient's laboratory results show that his white blood cell count is 6.1 K/uL, hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL, and platelet count is 289 K/uL. His liver function tests are elevated, with an ALT of 93, AP of 637, and LDH of 687. His electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 25 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 1.0 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory support is being provided through a tracheostomy tube, and he is receiving oxygen therapy with a flow rate of 40%. His ventilator settings include a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's assessment and plan include the following:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is being managed with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
* Tongue laceration: The patient's tongue biting has been ongoing for the past week or two, and he will be undergoing an EEG to rule out seizure activity.
* Abdominal distension: The patient's abdominal distension is unclear, and a KUB study has been ordered to assess for obstruction or perforation. Tube feeds have been held, and lipase and LFTs have been ordered to evaluate for pancreatitis.
* CHF: The patient appears volume-overloaded, and a CXR has been ordered to assess his volume status. He will be receiving IV furosemide and his home PO dose of lasix has been changed to IV.
* Hyperlipidemia: The patient is being continued on his home regimen of ASA, carvedilol, lisinopril, and lipitor.
* GERD: The patient is being continued on his home regimen of omeprazole 40 mg QD.
* Diabetes: The patient is being managed with Humalog SSI.
* FEN: The patient is being continued on his home regimen of MVI, B1, and folic acid.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and respiratory acidosis.
* Tongue laceration: Infection, bleeding, and potential airway compromise.
* Abdominal distension: Obstruction, perforation, and pancreatitis.
* CHF: Pulmonary edema, cardiogenic shock, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Hyperlipidemia: Pancreatitis, atherosclerosis, and cardiovascular events.
* GERD: Esophagitis, stricture, and Barrett's esophagus.
* Diabetes: Hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and hypoglycemia.
* FEN: Electrolyte imbalances, gastrointestinal bleeding, and malnutrition.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and gastrointestinal functions to prevent complications and ensure optimal care.

Summary:

The patient, a 43-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with anoxic brain injury, chronic respiratory failure with a tracheostomy in place, and a tongue laceration. He has a history of STEMI and is on various medications for his conditions. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a low-level MMV mode and is receiving furosemide (Lasix) intravenously. He has abdominal distension, which is thought to be due to air swallowing, and is awaiting a mouth guard from occupational health.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 103/70 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 100% on 40% FiO2. His respiratory support includes a tracheostomy tube, and he is receiving mechanical ventilation with a VT of 400 mL and a RR of 8.

The patient's physical examination reveals a tracheostomy tube in place, and he is easily arousable but non-verbal. He has a forked tongue with granulating tissue and no erythema or purulent drainage noted. His lungs are clear anteriorly, and his abdomen is distended with firmness.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.1 K/μL, hemoglobin of 9.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 289 K/μL. His creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, and his glucose is 81 mg/dL. His liver function tests are normal, and his lipase is 44.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure with a tracheostomy in place may lead to respiratory failure if not properly managed.
2. Abdominal distension: The patient's abdominal distension may lead to bowel obstruction or perforation if not managed properly.
3. Hyperkalemia: The patient's elevated potassium levels may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications if not managed properly.
4. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate chronic kidney disease, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
5. Seizure activity: The patient's history of anoxic brain injury and tongue biting may indicate seizure activity, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an infection, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
7. Heart failure: The patient's elevated blood pressure and peripheral edema may indicate heart failure, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old man with a complex medical history, including CAD, MI, VT storm, and anoxic brain injury resulting from a PEA arrest during a VT ablation procedure. He is currently in the ICU, receiving respiratory support with a tracheostomy tube and mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a Tmax of 38.3°C, HR of 79 bpm, BP of 96/62 mmHg, RR of 25 inspirations per minute, and SpO2 of 100%. He has a tongue laceration and is at risk for tongue biting, which may be related to seizure activity.

The patient has several medical complications, including respiratory failure, chronic systolic heart failure, and possible DVT. He is receiving various medications, including furosemide, heparin, lisinopril, carvedilol, and lipitor. His lab results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and electrolyte imbalances.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires ongoing mechanical ventilation and oxygen support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's anoxic brain injury and prolonged ICU stay increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. DVT: The patient's LUE edema and lack of radial pulses increase his risk of developing DVT, which could lead to pulmonary embolism.
4. Heart failure: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure may worsen due to his ongoing medical conditions and medications.
5. Neurological deficits: The patient's anoxic brain injury may result in long-term neurological deficits, including cognitive impairment and memory loss.
6. Infection: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and use of invasive lines and tubes increase his risk of developing infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and constipation may worsen due to his underlying medical conditions and medications.
8. Skin breakdown: The patient's immobility and pressure ulcers increase his risk of developing skin breakdown and pressure ulcers.

Recommendations:

1. Continue respiratory support with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs closely and adjust his medications as needed.
3. Perform a thorough neurological examination to assess the patient's cognitive and motor function.
4. Consider performing a head CT or MRI to evaluate the patient's brain injury.
5. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and adjust his insulin therapy as needed.
6. Perform a thorough physical examination to assess the patient's overall condition and identify any potential complications.
7. Consider performing a stress test or echocardiogram to evaluate the patient's cardiac function.
8. Monitor the patient's laboratory results closely and adjust his medications and therapy as needed.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with an anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG and tracheostomy, after a PEA arrest on the EP table. He is currently in the ICU with a range of medical issues.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 104.5°F (spiked to 104.5°F)
* Heart rate: 95 bpm (normal range)
* Blood pressure: 107/69 mmHg (normal range)
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute (normal range)
* Oxygen saturation: 100% (normal range)

The patient has several medical issues, including:

* Bacteremia: High-grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive, speciation and sensitivities pending.
* Respiratory failure, chronic: The patient has a tracheostomy and is on ventilator support.
* Aspiration pneumonia: Sputum culture is positive for aspiration pneumonia.
* Left upper extremity thrombus: US showed thrombus of brachial vein.
* Tongue laceration: The patient has a tongue laceration and is at risk for further injury.
* Abdominal distension: The patient has moderate abdominal distension and firmness, with no tenderness or pain.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further elevation.

The patient's medications include:

* Vanc (vancomycin) for bacteremia
* Levo/Flagyl for aspiration pneumonia
* Lasix (furosemide) for congestive heart failure
* Spironolactone for hyperkalemia (held for now)
* Tylenol for comfort

The patient's laboratory results include:

* White blood cell count: 11.0 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 30.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 301 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Glucose: 181 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: sodium 138 mmol/L, potassium 5.0 mmol/L, chloride 103 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies include:

* Upper extremity ultrasound: showed thrombus of brachial vein.
* Chest X-ray: showed chronic respiratory failure.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue Vanc for bacteremia
* Daily surveillance cultures
* Discuss further workup with EP cardiology, particularly regarding hardware in the heart
* Consider thrombus as possible source of bacteremia
* Consider Gent (gentamicin) if the patient fails to improve or continues to spike
* Continue Levo/Flagyl for aspiration pneumonia
* CXR tomorrow
* Restart tube feeds
* Optimize bowel regimen
* Monitor potassium levels and adjust medications as necessary
* Consider more aggressive diuresis if evidence of fluid overload
* Restart lasix 20mg Qday
* Repeat CXR to assess heart size (hopefully with better inspiration)

The patient's disposition is uncertain, but he may be transferred to a rehabilitation facility after a mouth guard is obtained.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with a history of anoxic brain injury, PEG and tracheostomy, and a recent PEA arrest. He is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure and bacteremia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 104.5°F, heart rate 95 bpm, blood pressure 107/69 mmHg, respiratory rate 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100% on a tracheal mask.
* Physical examination: The patient is tracheally intubated and ventilated, with a forked tongue from a recent laceration and granulating tissue. He has prominent lip smacking and teeth grinding. His lungs are clear anteriorly, and his abdomen is distended with firmness, but no tenderness or guarding.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 11.0 K/uL, hemoglobin is 30.6 g/dL, platelet count is 301 K/uL, and creatinine is 1.2 mg/dL. His blood cultures grew Gram-positive cocci in clusters.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures grew Gram-positive cocci in clusters, which could indicate a bloodstream infection.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is requiring mechanical ventilation.
3. Abdominal distension: The patient's abdomen is distended, which could be due to air swallowing or another underlying cause.
4. Left upper extremity swelling: The patient has swelling in his left upper extremity, which could be due to a deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is elevated, which could be due to various causes, including kidney disease or medications.
6. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac status is uncertain, and he may be at risk for cardiac failure due to his underlying medical conditions.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for his bacteremia.
2. Ventilator support: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory status.
3. Fluid management: The patient is receiving fluid management to address his abdominal distension and potential cardiac failure.
4. Pain management: The patient is receiving pain management with Tylenol for comfort.
5. Rehabilitation: The patient may be able to return to rehabilitation after his mouth guard is obtained and his medical condition is stabilized.

Overall, the patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, and his treatment plan should be closely monitored and adjusted as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy and anoxic brain injury, admitted for increased biting, requiring an oral appliance. He has been febrile and has GPC bacteremia with multiple positive blood cultures. The patient has valvular disease and an ICD. He is currently receiving vancomycin and is being treated for respiratory failure with a tracheostomy mask. He has a uremic clot and will require anticoagulation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and febrile state increase the risk of developing sepsis, a life-threatening condition that can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may worsen if his respiratory support is not optimized, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
3. Uremic Clot: The patient's uremic clot may continue to propagate and cause further complications, such as pulmonary embolism or cerebral infarction.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's valvular disease and ICD may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's anoxic brain injury and current state of unresponsiveness increase the risk of neurological complications, such as further brain damage or seizures.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and use of antibiotics may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as Clostridioides difficile infection or antibiotic-associated diarrhea.
7. Venous Thromboembolism: The patient's immobility and use of anticoagulation therapy may increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

 .H/O [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
   43 yoM with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG & trach, after a PEA arrest on
   the EP table in [**9-/2202**] (pt was undergoing VT ablation); admitted with
   stable tongue lac from biting tongue.  Awaiting mouth guard from
   occupational health. Pt also presents with abdominal distension and L
   UE swelling, although no pain to palpation.
   .
   # GPC Bacteremia:  High grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive,
   speciation and sensitivities pending.
   - Continue Vanc D2; f/u with ID re: course of treatment
   - Daily surveillance cultures
   - Discuss further workup with EP cardiology, particularly regarding
   hardware in heart
   - Consider TTE vs TEE for ?endocarditis
   - Consider thrombus as possible source of bacteremia
   - Consider Gent if patient fails to improve or continues to spike
   .
   # Aspiration PNA:  Sputum cx c/w aspiration pna, pt noted to also have
   secretions and suspect high aspiration risk.  Sputum growing
   respiratory flora and GNR; however, this is not uncommon in pts with a
   trach, so will d/c antibiotics given admission CXR did not show
   infiltrates.
   - D/C Levo/Flagyl, D3/7; restart if status declines clinically
   .
   #. L UE Thrombus:  LUE US showed thrombus of brachial vein.
   - Discuss risk vs benefit of prophylaxis vs treatment of thrombus
   - Currently received Lovenox for anti-coagulation; consider changing to
   SC Heparin if he will undergo procedures
   .
   #. TONGUE LACERATION: On talking to the patient
s sister and mother
   further, it sounds like the patient
s tongue biting has been off and on
   for the last week or two since he was on medication
to bring down his
   K
   -- f/u EEG to make sure tongue biting is not seizure activity given his
   h/o anoxic injury
   -- hct at baseline; recheck in am but does not need daily labs if going
   to be in house for some time
   -- contact occupational therapy re: mouth guard
   -- f/u appt with OM surgery per note ([**Hospital 3348**] Clinic [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11173**])
   -- Tylenol for comfort
   - Contact [**Name (NI) 1244**] dentist for possible custom mouth guard
   .
   #. S/P ANOXIC BRAIN INJURY:
   - EEG to r/o seizure given lip smacking and teeth grinding,
   non-responsiveness to visual threat; f/u results
   -- cont trach/vent; requirements stable
   -- [**Name (NI) 5055**] (unclear what on at baseline; INR slightly elevated likely from
   nutrition)
   .
   #. ABD DISTENTION: unclear why he is distended; KUB ordered from Radius
   on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction. Two BMs overnight.
   Abdominal exam very tympanitic, with gush of air when peg tube
   accessed.  Continues to be non-tender. Reassuring labs (incl LFTs and
   lipase) and KUB.  Think pt
s distension likely due to air swallowing.
   -- will restart tube feeds
   -- optimize bowel regimen.
   .
   #. ? Hyperkalemia
   - d/c banana flakes from tube feeds
   -- will hold spironolactone for now.
   -- daily lytes
   .
   #. CHF: Pt appears volume up on exam, with sig peripheral edema (off
   baseline, per pt
s family), JVD difficult to assess.
   -- CXR to assess vol status
 consider more aggressive diuresis if
   evidence of fluid overload
 none seen
   -- changed home PO dose lasix to IV (home dose is 20 mg; will give 10
   mg IV given c/f gut edema and not absorbing PO
   -- holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K
   -- restart lasix 20mg Qday
   -- repeat CXR to assess heart size (hopefully with better inspiration)
   .
   #. HYPERLIPIDEMIA, h/o STEMI:
   -- cont home regimen of ASA, carvedolol, lisinopril, lipitor
   .
   #. GERD: cont home omeprazole 40 mg QD
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- humalog SSI
   .
   #. FEN:  Tube feeds
   -- cont home MVI, B1, folic acid
   -- per pt care referral form, on replete with fiber at 70 cc/hr, free
   water flushes 200 ml Q6 hours --> NPO for now given abd distention
   .
   #. ACCESS: one PIV on right
   .
   #. PPX: -- Lovenox, [**Month/Year (2) 5055**], bowel regimen, home omeprazole
   .
   #. CODE: FULL
   .
   #. ICU consent: signed and in chart
   .
   #. DISPO: ICU care for infection
   ICU Care

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG and trach, and a history of VT ablation. He was admitted with a stable tongue laceration from biting his tongue. The patient has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea, and has been diagnosed with bacteremia, respiratory failure, and chronic.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 39.1°C (102.3°F), Tcurrent 37.6°C (99.6°F), HR 93 bpm, BP 97/62 mmHg, RR 33 inspirations per minute, SpO2 100%.
* Respiratory support: O2 delivery device: T-piece, SpO2: 100%, ABG: //25/.
* Physical examination: General: tracheostomy, awake but non-verbal and non-interactive, does not follow commands or track. No blink response to visual threat. HEENT: forked tongue from laceration with granulating tissue, Cardio: RRR, GIII systolic murmur at LSB, Lungs: CTA anteriorly, rhonchi upper airway sounds bilaterally, Abd: + BS, PEG; abdominal distension/firmness, tympanitic, no TTP, Extremities: 2+ bilateral LE and UE (L > R).

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* WBC: 6.1, 11.0, 8.2
* Hct: 32.5, 30.6, 33.1
* Plt: 292 K/uL, 10.0 g/dL, 113 mg/dL
* Cr: 1.0, 1.2, 0.9
* Glucose: 81, 181, 113
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 18.8/46.1/1.7, ALT / AST: 76/92, Alk Phos / T Bili: 605/1.3, Albumin: 2.6 g/dL, LDH: 236 IU/L, Ca++: 8.5 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 3.5 mg/dL

The patient's microbiology results are as follows:

* Respiratory culture: moderate growth of commensal respiratory flora, sparse growth of Gram-negative rods.
* MRSA in blood culture.

The patient's assessment and plan are as follows:

* Bacteremia: high-grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive, speciation and sensitivities pending. Continue Vanc D2, f/u with ID re: course of treatment, daily surveillance cultures.
* Respiratory failure, chronic: continue trach/vent, requirements stable.
* L UE thrombus: discuss risk vs benefit of prophylaxis vs treatment of thrombus, currently received Lovenox for anti-coagulation, consider changing to SC Heparin if he will undergo procedures.
* Tongue laceration: f/u EEG to make sure tongue biting is not seizure activity given his h/o anoxic injury, contact occupational therapy re: mouth guard.
* S/P anoxic brain injury: EEG to r/o seizure given lip smacking and teeth grinding, non-responsiveness to visual threat; f/u results.
* Abd distension: unclear why he is distended, KUB ordered from Radius on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction, two BMs overnight, abdominal exam very tympanitic, with gush of air when peg tube accessed, continues to be non-tender, think pt's distension likely due to air swallowing. Restart tube feeds, optimize bowel regimen.
*? Hyperkalemia: d/c banana flakes from tube feeds, hold spironolactone for now, daily lytes.
* CHF: pt appears volume up on exam, with sig peripheral edema (off baseline, per pt's family), JVD difficult to assess. CXR to assess vol status, consider more aggressive diuresis if evidence of fluid overload.

The patient's potential medical complications are as follows:

* Sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Endocarditis
* Thrombosis
* Hyperkalemia
* CHF
* Hyperlipidemia
* GERD
* Diabetes
* Fen
* Access
* PPX

The patient's code status is full code.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with a history of anoxic brain injury, PEA arrest, and various medical conditions. The patient has been experiencing fever, bacteremia, respiratory failure, and other complications.

The patient's current vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 102.3°F (39.1°C)
* Heart rate: 93 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 97/62 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 33 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General: trach, awake but non-verbal and non-interactive, does not follow commands or track, no blink response to visual threat
* HEENT: forked tongue from laceration with granulating tissue
* Cardio: RRR, GIII systolic murmur at LSB and apex
* Lungs: CTA anteriorly
* Abd: + BS, PEG; moderate abdominal distension/firmness, no tenderness to palpation
* Extremities: 2+ bilateral LE and UE (L > R)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 292 K/uL
* Hct: 33.1%
* Plt: 8.2 K/uL
* Cr: 1.0 mg/dL
* Glucose: 113 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 18.8/46.1/1.7, ALT/AST: 76/92, Alk Phos/T Bili: 605/1.3, Albumin: 2.6 g/dL, LDH: 236 IU/L, Ca++: 8.5 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 3.5 mg/dL

The patient has been diagnosed with bacteremia, respiratory failure, chronic, and aspiration pneumonia. He is also at risk for endocarditis, thrombus, and hyperkalemia.

The plan of care includes:

* Continuing vancomycin and daily surveillance cultures
* Discussing further workup with EP cardiology, particularly regarding hardware in the heart
* Considering TTE vs TEE for possible endocarditis
* Considering thrombus as a possible source of bacteremia
* Continuing Levo/Flagyl for aspiration pneumonia
* CXR tomorrow
* Discussing risk vs benefit of prophylaxis vs treatment of thrombus
* Willing to be anti-coagulated
* Checking EEG to rule out seizure activity given the patient's history of anoxic brain injury
* Contacting occupational therapy regarding a mouth guard
* Following up with OM surgery per note
* Using Tylenol for comfort
* Restarting tube feeds
* Optimizing bowel regimen
* Holding spironolactone for now
* Restarting lasix 20mg Qday
* Repeating CXR to assess heart size
* Obtaining c. diff, b. cxr, u. cxr, and sputum cxr
* Continuing home regimen of ASA, carvedolol, lisinopril, and lipitor
* Continuing home omeprazole 40mg QD
* Humalog SSI
* Contingency plan for FEN: tube feeds
* Contingency plan for DIABETES: humalog SSI
* Contingency plan for GERD: cont home omeprazole 40mg QD

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU care for infection.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient, a 42-year-old man, is a critical care patient in the ICU with an anoxic brain injury, MRSA bacteremia, and chronic systolic heart failure. He has been off the ventilator and doing well, with no evidence of aspiration pneumonia. The patient has a brachial vein thrombosis and is receiving lovenox prophylaxis. He also has a mural thrombus and a tongue laceration.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 112/79 mmHg. His respiratory support includes oxygen delivery through a T-piece, with a SpO2 of 100%. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.1, hemoglobin of 10.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 292 K/uL.

The patient is receiving several medications, including vancomycin for MRSA bacteremia, levofloxacin and metronidazole for suspected aspiration pneumonia, and lovenox for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis. He is also receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis against pulmonary embolism and stress ulcer prophylaxis with a proton pump inhibitor.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has MRSA bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis if not properly managed.
2. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient has a brachial vein thrombosis and is receiving lovenox prophylaxis, but there is a risk of developing deep vein thrombosis if the prophylaxis is not effective.
3. Pulmonary embolism: The patient is at risk of developing pulmonary embolism due to his chronic systolic heart failure and the presence of a mural thrombus.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure, which can worsen if not properly managed.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk of gastrointestinal bleeding due to his chronic systolic heart failure and the use of anticoagulant medications.
6. Seizure: The patient has a tongue laceration and is at risk of developing a seizure if not properly managed.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with a complex medical history, including anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG and trach, after a PEA arrest on the EP table. He is currently in the ICU with multiple comorbidities.

The patient has been diagnosed with bacteremia, likely caused by a central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). He is receiving vancomycin and daily surveillance cultures are being performed. The patient's bacteremia is high-grade, with 6/6 bottles positive, and speciation and sensitivities are pending.

The patient also has respiratory failure, chronic, and is requiring ventilatory support. He has a tracheostomy and is being weaned from the ventilator. His respiratory status is stable, with an ABG showing a pH of 7.27.

The patient has abdominal distension, likely caused by air swallowing, and is being managed with a bowel regimen and slow reintroduction of tube feeds. He also has a left upper extremity thrombus, which is being treated with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH).

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, including alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT), which may indicate liver dysfunction or obstruction. He also has hyperlipidemia and is being treated with lipid-lowering therapy.

The patient's medication list includes anticoagulation therapy with LMWH, as well as medications for his respiratory and cardiac conditions.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to the bacteremia and central line infection.
2. Respiratory failure and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the patient's chronic respiratory failure and tracheostomy.
3. Abdominal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation, due to the patient's abdominal distension and bowel regimen.
4. Thrombotic events, such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis, due to the patient's left upper extremity thrombus and anticoagulation therapy.
5. Liver dysfunction or failure due to the patient's elevated liver enzymes and potential liver obstruction.
6. Cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias, due to the patient's chronic cardiac condition and medication regimen.

The patient's care plan includes ongoing monitoring and management of his bacteremia, respiratory failure, abdominal distension, and thrombotic events. He will also require close monitoring of his liver enzymes and cardiac status.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old man with anoxic brain injury post-cardiac arrest, MRSA bacteremia, and chronic respiratory failure. He received antibiotics, including levofloxacin, metronidazole, and vancomycin. He is currently receiving infusions of lorazepam, fentanyl, and midazolam. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 120/84 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. His coagulation studies show elevated prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, and international normalized ratio.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, normal cardiovascular and respiratory examination, and soft, non-tender abdomen. His neurologic examination shows no attentive or following simple commands, and he responds to stimuli.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's MRSA bacteremia and elevated white blood cell count may lead to sepsis, which can cause organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to respiratory arrest and death.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest history and ongoing cardiac instability may increase the risk of cardiac arrest and death.
4. Neurological injury: The patient's anoxic brain injury may worsen, leading to permanent brain damage and disability.
5. Infection: The patient's bacteremia may lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
6. Bleeding: The patient's coagulation disorders may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and malnutrition may lead to deficiencies in essential nutrients, such as protein, vitamins, and minerals.
8. Medication side effects: The patient's medication regimen may cause side effects, such as respiratory depression, sedation, or bleeding, which may worsen his condition.

   .
   43 yoM with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG & trach, after a PEA arrest on
   the EP table in [**9-/2202**] (pt was undergoing VT ablation); admitted with
   stable tongue lac from biting tongue.  Awaiting mouth guard from
   occupational health. Pt also presents with abdominal distension and L
   UE swelling, although no pain to palpation.
   .
   # GPC Bacteremia:  High grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive,
   speciation and sensitivities pending.
   - f/u ID recs (etiology?)
   - Continue Vanc 1g q12h; trough today ok so cont this dosing
   - Daily surveillance cultures
   - Discuss further workup with EP cardiology, particularly regarding
   hardware in heart
   - Consider thrombus as possible source of bacteremia
   - Consider Gent if patient fails to improve or continues to spike
   .
   # Aspiration PNA:  Resolved. Sputum cx c/w aspiration pna, pt noted to
   also have secretions and suspect high aspiration risk.  Sputum growing
   respiratory flora and GNR; however, this is not uncommon in pts with a
   trach, so will d/c antibiotics given admission CXR did not show
   infiltrates.
   - Restart levo/flagyl if status declines clinically
   .
   #. L UE Thrombus:  LUE US showed thrombus of brachial vein.
   - Lovenox for 6 months
   - Currently receiving Lovenox for anti-coagulation; consider changing
   to SC Heparin if he will undergo procedures
   .
   #. TONGUE LACERATION: On talking to the patient
s sister and mother
   further, it sounds like the patient
s tongue biting has been off and on
   for the last week or two since he was on medication
to bring down his
   K
. Improved yesterday/today.
   -- f/u with family re; dental plan and options
   -- f/u with social work
   -- f/u appt with OM surgery per note ([**Hospital 3348**] Clinic [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11173**])
   -- Tylenol for comfort
   -- f/u with prosthodontics specialist at [**Hospital1 1244**]
   -- continue ativan for anxiety component
   .
   #. S/P ANOXIC BRAIN INJURY:
   - EEG to r/o seizure given lip smacking and teeth grinding,
   non-responsiveness to visual threat; f/u results
   -- cont trach/vent; requirements stable
   .
   #. ABD DISTENTION: unclear why he is distended; KUB ordered from Radius
   on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction. Two BMs overnight.
   Abdominal exam very tympanitic, with gush of air when peg tube
   accessed.  Continues to be non-tender. Reassuring labs (incl LFTs and
   lipase) and KUB.  Think pt
s distension likely due to air swallowing.
   Mildly LFT
s today.
   -- continue tube feeds slowly
   -- continue bowel regimen
   -- f/u final read RUQ u/s
   -- hepatitis serologies pending
   -- trend daily LFTs
   .
   #. ? Hyperkalemia. Not hyperkalemic today.
   -- will hold spironolactone for now.
   -- daily lytes
   .
   #. CHF: Pt appears volume up on exam, with sig peripheral edema (off
   baseline, per pt
s family), JVD difficult to assess. Today not
   particularly volume overloaded.
   -- holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K
   -- continue lasix 20mg Qday
   .
   #. HYPERLIPIDEMIA, h/o STEMI:
   -- cont home regimen of ASA, carvedolol, lisinopril, lipitor
   .
   #. GERD: cont home omeprazole 40 mg QD
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- humalog SSI
   .
   #. FEN:
   -- cont home MVI, B1, folic acid
   -- per pt care referral form, tubefeeds, on replete with fiber at 70
   cc/hr, free water flushes 200 ml Q6 hours
   .
   #. ACCESS: PICC on right placed [**11-23**]
   .
   #. PPX: -- Lovenox for 6 months started mid-[**2202-11-2**], bowel
   regimen, home omeprazole
   .
   #. CODE: FULL
   .
   #. ICU consent: signed and in chart
   .
   #. DISPO: ICU today; sort out dental issues; likely d/c to rehab
   tomorrow AM

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities, including anoxic brain injury, tracheostomy, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube. The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, VT ablation, and has undergone various procedures.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiomegaly with severe tricuspid regurgitation and depressed left ventricular systolic function
* Moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation
* Pulmonary edema with right perihilar opacity and potentially similar opacity in the left perihilar area
* Abdominal distension with no evidence of obstruction
* Left upper extremity swelling with no pain to palpation
* Impaired skin integrity
* Bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive, speciation and sensitivities pending
* Aspiration pneumonia resolved, but with ongoing risk of aspiration
* Left upper extremity thrombus
* Tongue laceration with ongoing risk of biting

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* WBC: 6.1-7.7 K/uL
* Hct: 32.5-32.6%
* Plt: 335-92 K/uL
* Cr: 0.6-0.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 81-118 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 17.7/44.8/1.6, ALT/AST: 94/109, Alk Phos/T Bili: 654/1.3, Albumin: 2.5 g/dL, LDH: 201 IU/L, Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.8 mg/dL, PO4: 3.4 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Vancomycin: 1g q12h
* Fentanyl: 09:15 AM
* Midazolam (Versed): 09:20 AM
* Lorazepam (Ativan): 06:40 PM
* Levo/flagyl: pending
* Lovenox: 6 months
* Tylenol: for comfort
* Ativan: for anxiety component

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac failure due to cardiomegaly and tricuspid regurgitation
* Respiratory failure due to pulmonary edema and aspiration pneumonia
* Sepsis due to bacteremia
* Thrombosis due to left upper extremity thrombus
* Hyperkalemia due to potential electrolyte imbalance
* Hyperlipidemia due to ongoing medication regimen
* Gastrointestinal complications due to PEG tube and bowel regimen
* Infection due to tracheostomy and PEG tube

It is crucial to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG and trach, after a PEA arrest on the EP table. He has a history of STEMI, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has a moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation and severely depressed left ventricular systolic function, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure. He is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 100%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has cardiomegaly and a new retrocardiac opacity on his CXR, which may be pneumonia. He is receiving lasix and has a goal of 1L negative fluid balance.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has abdominal distension and is receiving tube feeds. He has a history of GERD and is taking omeprazole.
* Neurological: The patient has anoxic brain injury and is non-responsive. He has a tongue laceration and is receiving Ativan for anxiety.
* Hematological: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive, speciation and sensitivities pending. He is receiving Vancomycin and may need to be switched to Gentamicin if he fails to improve.
* Renal: The patient has a mild elevation in his creatinine and is receiving Lasix. He has a history of hyperkalemia and is being monitored.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his tricuspid regurgitation and left ventricular systolic function do not improve.
* Bacteremia: The patient's high-grade bacteremia may lead to sepsis and organ failure if not treated promptly and effectively.
* Pneumonia: The patient's CXR shows a new retrocardiac opacity, which may be pneumonia. If left untreated, pneumonia can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's creatinine is mildly elevated, and he has a history of hyperkalemia. If his potassium levels become elevated, it can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and arrest.
* Thrombosis: The patient has a thrombus in his brachial vein and is receiving Lovenox. If the thrombus breaks off and travels to his lungs or other vital organs, it can lead to serious complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and pneumonia make him at high risk for developing sepsis. Sepsis can lead to organ failure and death if not treated promptly and effectively.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is recommended that he receive close monitoring and treatment for his respiratory failure, bacteremia, and pneumonia. He should also be monitored for signs of hyperkalemia and thrombosis.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old man with an anoxic brain injury, MRSA bacteremia, and a tongue laceration. He is currently in the ICU and has been receiving various medications and treatments. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.3°C, heart rate of 103 bpm, and blood pressure of 148/86 mmHg. His respiratory support includes oxygen delivery through a T-piece and ABG results are within normal limits. His physical examination reveals no signs of distress, but his neurologic examination is abnormal, with no attentiveness, no follow of simple commands, and no response to stimuli.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's MRSA bacteremia and fever could lead to sepsis, which could worsen his already compromised neurological status.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and frothy pink sputum could worsen his respiratory status, leading to respiratory failure.
3. Thrombosis: The patient's UE thrombus and LV thrombus could lead to further complications, such as pulmonary embolism or stroke.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's chronic systolic HF and diuresis could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's MRSA bacteremia and hospital-acquired PNA could lead to further infections, such as pneumonia or septicemia.
6. Neurological deterioration: The patient's anoxic brain injury and abnormal neurologic examination could lead to further neurological deterioration.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance and diuresis could lead to fluid overload, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's replete with fiber and glycemic control could lead to malnutrition, which could worsen his overall health status.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and neurological status closely.
2. Continue antibiotics for MRSA bacteremia and add Zosyn for hospital-acquired PNA.
3. Continue lovenox for UE thrombus and LV thrombus.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and diuresis closely to prevent fluid overload.
5. Consider adding stress ulcer prophylaxis to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Consult with a prosthodontic specialist to address the patient's tongue laceration.
7. Consider adding a DVT prophylaxis to prevent thrombosis.
8. Monitor the patient's glycemic control and nutrition to prevent malnutrition.

   43 yoM with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG & trach, after a PEA arrest on

   stable tongue lac from biting tongue.  Awaiting mouth guard from
   occupational health. Pt also presents with abdominal distension and L
   UE swelling, although no pain to palpation.
   .
   # GPC Bacteremia:  High grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive,
   speciation and sensitivities pending.
   - f/u ID recs (etiology?)
   - Continue Vanc 1g q12h; trough today ok so cont this dosing
   - Keep cardiac hardware in place for now
   - Consider thrombus as possible source of bacteremia
   - Consider Gent if patient fails to improve or continues to spike
   .
   # Aspiration PNA:  Resolved. Sputum cx c/w aspiration pna, pt noted to
   also have secretions and suspect high aspiration risk.  Sputum growing
   respiratory flora and GNR; however, this is not uncommon in pts with a
   trach, so will d/c antibiotics given admission CXR did not show
   infiltrates. On [**11-24**], concern for aspiration pneumonia given fever,
   ?infiltrate on CXR.
   - Start zosyn for empiric coverage for pseudomonas pneumonia, D1=[**11-24**]
   for 8 day course (or 14 day course if proves to be true pseudomonas)
   - sputum culture today
   - daily CXR
   - f/u blood cultures (already cultured today)
   .
   #. L UE Thrombus:  LUE US showed thrombus of brachial vein.
   - Lovenox for 6 months
   - Currently receiving Lovenox for anti-coagulation; consider changing
   to SC Heparin if he will undergo procedures
   .
   #. TONGUE LACERATION: On talking to the patient
s sister and mother
   further, it sounds like the patient
s tongue biting has been off and on
   for the last week or two since he was on medication
to bring down his
   K
. Improved yesterday/today.
   -- f/u with family re; dental plan and options
   -- f/u with social work
   -- f/u appt with OM surgery per note ([**Hospital 3348**] Clinic [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11173**])
   -- Tylenol for comfort
   -- f/u with prosthodontics specialist at [**Hospital1 1244**] re: options
   -- continue ativan for anxiety component
   .
   #. S/P ANOXIC BRAIN INJURY:
   - EEG to r/o seizure given lip smacking and teeth grinding,
   non-responsiveness to visual threat; f/u results
   -- cont trach/vent; requirements stable
   .
   #. ABD DISTENTION: unclear why he is distended; KUB ordered from Radius
   on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction. Two BMs overnight.
   Abdominal exam very tympanitic, with gush of air when peg tube
   accessed.  Continues to be non-tender. Reassuring labs (incl LFTs and
   lipase) and KUB.  Think pt
s distension likely due to air swallowing.
   Mildly LFT
s today, stable. GGT elevated. Consider drugs versus biliary
   source.
   -- continue tube feeds slowly
   -- continue bowel regimen
   -- f/u final read RUQ u/s
   -- hepatitis serologies pending
   -- trend daily LFTs
   .
   #. ? Hyperkalemia. Not hyperkalemic today.
   -- will hold spironolactone for now.
   -- daily lytes
   .
   #. CHF: Pt appears volume up on exam, with sig peripheral edema (off
   baseline, per pt
s family), JVD difficult to assess. Today, pink frothy
   suctioning appears CHF-like plus volume on CXR.
   -- holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K
   -- continue lasix 20mg Qday (already received extra 40mg lasix today)
   -- goal 1L negative today, with lasix later prn
   .
   #. HYPERLIPIDEMIA, h/o STEMI:
   -- cont home regimen of ASA, carvedolol, lisinopril, lipitor
   .
   #. GERD: cont home omeprazole 40 mg QD
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- humalog SSI
   .
   #. FEN:
   -- cont home MVI, B1, folic acid
   -- per pt care referral form, tubefeeds, on replete with fiber at 70
   cc/hr, free water flushes 200 ml Q6 hours
   .
   #. ACCESS: PICC on right placed [**11-23**]
   .
   #. PPX: -- Lovenox for 6 months started mid-[**2202-11-2**], bowel
   regimen, home omeprazole
   .

   .

   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG & trach, and a history of VT ablation. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical conditions.

The patient has been experiencing fever, with a peak temperature of 38.3°C (101°F) on [**2202-11-24**] at 01:30 PM. He was started on Cefepime/Cipro to cover HAP. The patient's sputum culture is pending, but the initial results show growth of respiratory flora and GNR.

The patient has also been experiencing tongue biting, which has been ongoing for the past week or two. His tongue laceration has improved, but he still requires further evaluation and treatment.

The patient has a history of STEMI, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. He is currently on home medications for these conditions.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 6.1-7.7 K/μL
* Hct: 31.1-33.1%
* Plt: 335-347 K/μL
* Cr: 0.6-0.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 81-124 mg/dL
* LFTs: stable, with a mildly elevated GGT
* Lipase: normal
* K: 3.1-3.8 mmol/L
* Mg++: 1.7-2.6 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.6-3.1 mg/dL

The patient's chest X-ray shows a new retrocardiac opacity, which could be pneumonia.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue Vanc 1g q12h
* Start zosyn for empiric coverage for pseudomonas pneumonia
* Daily CXR
* F/u blood cultures
* Lovenox for 6 months
* Consider changing to SC Heparin if he will undergo procedures
* EEG to r/o seizure
* Continue trach/vent
* Trend daily LFTs
* F/u with family re: dental plan and options
* F/u with social work
* F/u appt with OM surgery
* Tylenol for comfort
* Continue Ativan for anxiety component

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Bacteremia
* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* Hyperkalemia
* CHF
* Hyperlipidemia
* Diabetes
* GERD
* Anoxic brain injury

The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and further evaluation and treatment are necessary to address these potential complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with a complex medical history, including anoxic brain injury, tracheostomy, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG). The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, chronic, and has a history of MRSA bacteremia, aspiration pneumonia, left upper extremity thrombus, and tongue laceration.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T-max 38.3°C, T-current 37.7°C, HR 84 bpm, BP 124/75 mmHg, RR 16 inspirations per minute, SpO2 100%.
* Respiratory support: O2 delivery device T-piece, FiO2 40%, ABG //27/.
* Cardiovascular system: RRR, III/VI SEM.
* Abdominal distension: +bs, likely due to air swallowing.
* Skin integrity: Impaired.
* Laboratory results: WBC 6.1 K/uL, Hct 32.5%, Plt 347 K/uL, Cr 1.0 mg/dL, Glucose 124 mg/dL.

The patient's medical complications are:

* Bacteremia: High-grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive on 11-20, negative cultures since then.
* Aspiration pneumonia: Resolved, but sputum growing respiratory flora and GNR.
* Left upper extremity thrombus: Lovenox for 6 months.
* Tongue laceration: CT Neck w/o contrast indicates obliteration of oropharynx, repeat CT Neck (now with contrast) for better look.
* Abdominal distension: unclear why, KUB ordered from Radius on 11-18 shows no evidence of obstruction.
* Chronic respiratory failure: PEG and trach, awaiting mouth guard from occupational health.
* Hyperlipidemia, h/o STEMI: cont home regimen of ASA, Lipitor, start carvedilol today.
* GERD: cont home omeprazole 40 mg QD.
* Diabetes: humalog SSI.
* Fen: cont home MVI, B1, folic acid.

The patient's plan of care is:

* Continue Vanc 1g q12h.
* Continue Cefepime/Cipro per ID recs, D1 = 11-24.
* Keep cardiac hardware in place for now.
* Repeat CT Neck (now with contrast) for better look.
* F/u OMFS recs -> currently no plans for surgery.
* Tylenol for comfort.
* Continue Ativan for anxiety component.
* Continue tube feeds slowly.
* Continue bowel regimen.
* RUQ u/s showed no stone, no cholecystitis and?nodularity to hepatic contour that may suggest underlying chronic liver disease.
* Hepatitis serologies pending.
* Trend daily LFTs.
* Holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K.
* Continue lasix 20mg Qday.
* Start carvedilol today.
* Continue holding home Lisinopril.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 42-year-old man with an anoxic brain injury, who has been in the ICU for several days. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 136/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on a T-piece device.

The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and has been restarted on carvedilol. He also has a history of MRSA bacteremia, which is currently negative.

The patient has impaired skin integrity, with a notation that his tongue lacerations may have been caused by the extraction of two teeth. He is being monitored for further bleeding.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a range of 6.1-11.0 K/uL. His hemoglobin level is 9.4 g/dL, and his platelet count is 92 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.7 mEq/L.

The patient is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis with low-molecular-weight heparin and stress ulcer prophylaxis with a proton pump inhibitor. He is also receiving nutrition via a PICC line, with a rate of 70 mL/hour.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's history of MRSA bacteremia and his current impaired skin integrity make him susceptible to developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and his current need for oxygen therapy make him at risk for developing respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of chronic systolic heart failure and his current treatment with carvedilol make him at risk for developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure exacerbation.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's anoxic brain injury and his current impaired skin integrity make him at risk for developing neurological complications, such as seizures or increased intracranial pressure.
5. Infection: The patient's impaired skin integrity and his history of MRSA bacteremia make him at risk for developing infections, particularly skin and soft tissue infections.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

   43 yoM with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG & trach, after a PEA arrest on
   the EP table in [**9-/2202**] (pt was undergoing VT ablation); admitted with
   stable tongue lac from biting tongue, found to be bacteremic with MRSA.
   .
   # MRSA Bacteremia:  High grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive on
   [**11-20**], negative cultures since then.
   - f/u ID recs
   - continue Vanc 1g q12h (course is for 4 weeks from last neg culture on
   [**11-21**])
   - continue Cefepime/Cipro per ID recs for possible VAP, D1 = [**11-24**]
   (course is for 7 days to end on [**12-1**])
   - keep cardiac hardware in place for now, ECHO showed no endocarditis
   .
   # Aspiration PNA:  Resolved. Sputum cx c/w aspiration pna, pt noted to
   also have secretions and suspect high aspiration risk.  Sputum growing
   respiratory flora and GNR; however, this is not uncommon in pts with a
   trach, so will d/c antibiotics given admission CXR did not show
   infiltrates. On [**11-24**], concern for aspiration pneumonia given fever,
   ?infiltrate on CXR.
   - continue abx as above
   - f/u sputum cx
   - no more daily surveillance blood cx
   .
   #. L UE Thrombus:  LUE US showed thrombus of brachial vein.
   - continue Lovenox (for 6 months)
   .
   #. TONGUE LACERATION: On talking to the patient
s sister and mother
   further, it sounds like the patient
s tongue biting has been off and on
   for the last week or two since he was on medication
to bring down his
   K
.  Pt bit off some tongue on [**11-25**], OMFS came by, pulled out 2 loose
   teeth that were thought to be the culprit.
   -- f/u CT Neck w/contrast
   -- f/u OMFS recs -> currently no plans for surgery
   -- Tylenol for comfort
   -- continue ativan for anxiety component
   .
   #. S/P ANOXIC BRAIN INJURY:
   -- CT head shows stable reduction in [**Doctor Last Name 734**]-white differentiation,
   unchanged from previous
   -- f/u EEG results
   -- cont trach/vent; requirements stable
   .
   #. ABD DISTENTION: unclear why he is distended; KUB ordered from Radius
   on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction. Two BMs overnight.
   Abdominal exam very tympanitic, with gush of air when peg tube
   accessed.  Continues to be non-tender. Reassuring labs (incl LFTs and
   lipase) and KUB.  Think pt
s distension likely due to air swallowing.
   Mildly LFT
s today, stable. GGT elevated. Consider drugs versus biliary
   source.
   -- continue tube feeds slowly
   -- continue bowel regimen
   -- RUQ u/s showed no stone, no cholecystitis and ?nodularity to hepatic
   contour that may suggest underlying chronic liver disease
   -- Hep panel neg for HepB or C infections
   -- trend daily LFTs
   .
   #. CHF: Pt appears volume up on exam, with sig peripheral edema (off
   baseline, per pt
s family), JVD difficult to assess. Today, pink frothy
   suctioning appears CHF-like plus volume on CXR.
   -- holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K
   -- continue lasix 20mg Qday
   -- increase Carvedilol to home dose of 25mg [**Hospital1 **] today
   -- continue holding home Lisinopril, consider restarting tomorrow
   -- goal 1L negative today, with lasix later prn
   .

   -- cont home regimen of ASA, Lipitor
   -- increase Carvedilol to home dose of 25mg [**Hospital1 **] today
   .
   #. GERD: cont home omeprazole 40 mg QD

   .
   # MRSA Bacteremia:  High grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive on
   [**11-20**], negative cultures since then.
   - f/u ID recs
   - continue Vanc 1g q12h (course is for 4 weeks from last neg culture on
   [**11-21**])
   - continue Cefepime/Cipro per ID recs for possible VAP, D1 = [**11-24**]
   (course is for 7 days to end on [**12-1**])
   - keep cardiac hardware in place for now, ECHO showed no endocarditis
   .
   # Aspiration PNA:  Resolved. Sputum cx c/w aspiration pna, pt noted to
   also have secretions and suspect high aspiration risk.  Sputum growing
   respiratory flora and GNR; however, this is not uncommon in pts with a
   trach, so will d/c antibiotics given admission CXR did not show
   infiltrates. On [**11-24**], concern for aspiration pneumonia given fever,
   ?infiltrate on CXR.
   - continue abx as above
   - f/u sputum cx
   - no more daily surveillance blood cx
   .
   #. L UE Thrombus:  LUE US showed thrombus of brachial vein.
   - continue Lovenox (for 6 months)
   .
   #. TONGUE LACERATION: On talking to the patient
s sister and mother
   further, it sounds like the patient
s tongue biting has been off and on
   for the last week or two since he was on medication
to bring down his
   K
.  Pt bit off some tongue on [**11-25**], OMFS came by, pulled out 2 loose
   teeth that were thought to be the culprit.
   -- f/u CT Neck w/contrast
   -- f/u OMFS recs -> currently no plans for surgery
   -- Tylenol for comfort
   -- continue ativan for anxiety component
   .
   #. S/P ANOXIC BRAIN INJURY:
   -- CT head shows stable reduction in [**Doctor Last Name 734**]-white differentiation,
   unchanged from previous
   -- f/u EEG results
   -- cont trach/vent; requirements stable
   .
   #. ABD DISTENTION: unclear why he is distended; KUB ordered from Radius
   on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction. Two BMs overnight.
   Abdominal exam very tympanitic, with gush of air when peg tube
   accessed.  Continues to be non-tender. Reassuring labs (incl LFTs and
   lipase) and KUB.  Think pt
s distension likely due to air swallowing.
   Mildly LFT
s today, stable. GGT elevated. Consider drugs versus biliary

   -- continue tube feeds slowly

   -- RUQ u/s showed no stone, no cholecystitis and ?nodularity to hepatic

   baseline, per pt
s family), JVD difficult to assess. Today, pink frothy

   -- holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K

   .

   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old male with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG and trach, after a PEA arrest on the EP table. He is currently in the ICU due to bacteremia with MRSA, respiratory failure, chronic, and other comorbidities.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on T-piece with 100% oxygen saturation, and his ABG shows pH 7.27.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a sinus rhythm, and his blood pressure is 117/77 mmHg.
* Neurological status: The patient is unresponsive to voice or touch, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 3.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has abdominal distension, which is thought to be due to air swallowing. He has a tracheostomy and is on tube feeds.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine level is 1.0 mg/dL, and his urine output is 1,170 mL.
* Hematological status: The patient has a white blood cell count of 6.1 K/uL, and his platelet count is 304 K/uL.
* Infectious status: The patient has a positive blood culture for MRSA, and his sputum culture is growing respiratory flora and GNR.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia with MRSA increases his risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure can worsen, leading to respiratory arrest or failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of STEMI and hyperlipidemia increases his risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and constipation can lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's anoxic brain injury and neurological status can worsen, leading to further neurological decline or complications.
6. Renal complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease and creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL increase his risk of developing renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.
7. Hematological complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and white blood cell count of 6.1 K/uL increase his risk of developing hematological complications, such as bleeding or infection.
8. Infectious complications: The patient's positive blood culture for MRSA and sputum culture growing respiratory flora and GNR increase his risk of developing infectious complications, such as pneumonia or sepsis.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, renal, hematological, and infectious status.

   occupational health. Pt also presents with abdominal distension and L
   UE swelling, although no pain to palpation.
   .
   # MRSA Bacteremia:  High grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive on
   [**11-20**], negative cultures since then.
   - f/u ID recs
   - Continue Vanc 1g q12h

   - Keep cardiac hardware in place for now

s sister and mother

s tongue biting has been off and on

to bring down his

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a PEA arrest on the EP table during a VT ablation procedure. He has an anoxic brain injury, tracheostomy, and PEG tube. He has a history of MRSA bacteremia, aspiration pneumonia, left upper extremity thrombus, tongue laceration, and anoxic brain injury.

The patient's current condition is:

* Impaired skin integrity: The patient has a tongue laceration and a history of MRSA bacteremia.
* Bacteremia: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive on 11/20, but negative cultures since then.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure and is on a tracheostomy.
* Abdominal distension: The patient has abdominal distension, which is likely due to air swallowing.
* LFT elevation: The patient has mildly elevated LFTs, which may be due to drugs or biliary source.
* CHF: The patient appears volume overloaded and has signs of CHF.
* Hyperlipidemia: The patient has a history of STEMI and is on home medications.
* GERD: The patient has a history of GERD and is on home omeprazole.
* Diabetes: The patient has diabetes and is on Humalog SSI.
* FEN: The patient is on tube feeds and has a PICC line.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of MRSA bacteremia and is at risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure and is at risk of developing respiratory failure.
3. Abdominal complications: The patient has abdominal distension and is at risk of developing abdominal complications such as perforation or bleeding.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient has CHF and is at risk of developing cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
5. Infection: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is at risk of developing other infections such as urinary tract infections or bloodstream infections.
6. Thrombosis: The patient has a left upper extremity thrombus and is at risk of developing other thrombotic events.
7. Anoxic brain injury: The patient has an anoxic brain injury and is at risk of developing further neurological damage.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of GERD and is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy for MRSA bacteremia.
2. Continue respiratory support for chronic respiratory failure.
3. Monitor for signs of sepsis and respiratory failure.
4. Manage abdominal distension with tube feeds and free water flushes.
5. Monitor for signs of CHF and cardiac complications.
6. Monitor for signs of infection and thrombosis.
7. Continue neurological monitoring for signs of anoxic brain injury.
8. Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I have summarized the patient's current condition and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 43-year-old male with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG and trach, after a PEA arrest on the EP table.
* He is bacteremic with MRSA and has a history of tongue biting and bleeding.
* He has respiratory failure, chronic, and is on mechanical ventilation.
* He has impaired skin integrity, and there is a concern for aspiration pneumonia.
* He has a left upper extremity thrombus and is on anticoagulation therapy.
* He has abdominal distension, which is likely due to air swallowing.
* He has mild hyperlipidemia and a history of STEMI.
* He has diabetes and is on tube feeds.
* He has a PICC line and is at risk for catheter-related complications.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Bacteremia with MRSA may lead to sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.
* Aspiration pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and death.
* Left upper extremity thrombus may lead to pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, and post-thrombotic syndrome.
* Abdominal distension may lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, and sepsis.
* Hyperlipidemia may lead to pancreatitis, cardiovascular events, and stroke.
* Diabetes may lead to ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome, and chronic complications such as nephropathy and retinopathy.
* Impaired skin integrity may lead to pressure ulcers, infections, and sepsis.

**Plan:**

* Continue antibiotics for MRSA bacteremia and aspiration pneumonia.
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and septic shock.
* Continue anticoagulation therapy for left upper extremity thrombus.
* Monitor for signs of bowel obstruction and perforation.
* Continue tube feeds and monitor for signs of malnutrition.
* Monitor for signs of hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular events.
* Monitor for signs of diabetes complications and adjust therapy as needed.
* Monitor for signs of impaired skin integrity and take measures to prevent pressure ulcers and infections.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

The patient is a 43-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG and trach, after a PEA arrest on the EP table. He was found to be bacteremic with MRSA. The patient has been experiencing several complications, including:

1. Acute anemia: The patient has a significant drop in hemoglobin levels, from 32.5 to 25.1%, and is at risk of further decline.
2. MRSA Bacteremia: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive on [**11-20**], and negative cultures since then.
3. Aspiration PNA: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia, and there is concern for further aspiration risk.
4. L UE Thrombus: The patient has a thrombus in the brachial vein.
5. Tongue Laceration: The patient has a tongue laceration that is not healing, and there is concern for further bleeding.
6. S/P Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient has a stable reduction in [**Doctor Last Name 734**]-white differentiation, unchanged from previous.
7. ABD Distention: The patient has abdominal distention, which is likely due to air swallowing.
8. CHF: The patient appears volume-up on exam, with significant peripheral edema, and there is concern for further fluid overload.
9. Hyperlipidemia, h/o STEMI: The patient has a history of STEMI and is at risk for further cardiovascular complications.
10. GERD: The patient has a history of GERD and is taking home omeprazole.
11. Diabetes: The patient has diabetes and is no longer requiring insulin.
12. FEN: The patient is taking home MVI, B1, and folic acid, and is on tube feeds with free water flushes.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's high-grade bacteremia and acute anemia increase the risk of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of aspiration pneumonia and chronic respiratory failure increase the risk of further respiratory decline.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of STEMI, CHF, and hyperlipidemia increase the risk of further cardiovascular complications.
4. Neurological decline: The patient's history of anoxic brain injury and ongoing respiratory and cardiovascular complications increase the risk of further neurological decline.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of GERD, ABD distention, and ongoing tube feeds increase the risk of further gastrointestinal complications.
6. Infection: The patient's ongoing bacteremia and history of aspiration pneumonia increase the risk of further infection.

Given the patient's complex medical status, close monitoring and management are essential to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
   43 yoM with anoxic brain injury, s/p PEG & trach, after a PEA arrest on
   the EP table in [**9-/2202**] (pt was undergoing VT ablation); admitted with
   stable tongue lac from biting tongue, found to be bacteremic with MRSA.
   .
   # Acute anemia:
   - f/u repeat Hct
   - consider guiac stool
   - PM Hct
   .
   # MRSA Bacteremia:  High grade bacteremia with 6/6 bottles positive on
   [**11-20**], negative cultures since then.
   - f/u ID recs
   - continue Vanc 1g q12h (course is for 4 weeks from last neg culture on
   [**11-21**])
   - continue Cefepime/Cipro per ID recs for possible VAP, D1 = [**11-24**]
   (course is for 7 days to end on [**12-1**])
   - keep cardiac hardware in place for now, ECHO showed no endocarditis
   .
   # Aspiration PNA:  Resolved. Sputum cx c/w aspiration pna, pt noted to
   also have secretions and suspect high aspiration risk.  Sputum growing
   respiratory flora and GNR; however, this is not uncommon in pts with a
   trach, so will d/c antibiotics given admission CXR did not show
   infiltrates. On [**11-24**], concern for aspiration pneumonia given fever,
   ?infiltrate on CXR.
   - continue abx as above
   - f/u sputum cx
   - no more daily surveillance blood cx
   .
   #. L UE Thrombus:  LUE US showed thrombus of brachial vein.
   - continue Lovenox (for 6 months)
   .
   #. TONGUE LACERATION: On talking to the patient
s sister and mother
   further, it sounds like the patient
s tongue biting has been off and on
   for the last week or two since he was on medication
to bring down his
   K
.  Pt bit off some tongue on [**11-25**], OMFS came by, pulled out 2 loose
   teeth that were thought to be the culprit.
   -- f/u CT Neck w/contrast
   -- f/u OMFS recs -> currently no plans for surgery
   -- Tylenol for comfort
   -- continue ativan for anxiety component
   .
   #. S/P ANOXIC BRAIN INJURY:
   -- CT head shows stable reduction in [**Doctor Last Name 734**]-white differentiation,
   unchanged from previous
   -- f/u EEG results
   -- cont trach/vent; requirements stable
   .
   #. ABD DISTENTION: unclear why he is distended; KUB ordered from Radius
   on [**11-18**] shows no evidence of obstruction. Two BMs overnight.
   Abdominal exam very tympanitic, with gush of air when peg tube
   accessed.  Continues to be non-tender. Reassuring labs (incl LFTs and
   lipase) and KUB.  Think pt
s distension likely due to air swallowing.
   Mildly LFT
s today, stable. GGT elevated. Consider drugs versus biliary
   source.
   -- continue tube feeds slowly
   -- continue bowel regimen
   -- RUQ u/s showed no stone, no cholecystitis and ?nodularity to hepatic
   contour that may suggest underlying chronic liver disease
   -- Hep panel neg for HepB or C infections
   -- trend daily LFTs
   .
   #. CHF: Pt appears volume up on exam, with sig peripheral edema (off
   baseline, per pt
s family), JVD difficult to assess. Today, pink frothy
   suctioning appears CHF-like plus volume on CXR.
   -- holding spironolactone for now, while monitoring K
   -- continue lasix 20mg Qday
   -- increase Carvedilol to home dose of 25mg [**Hospital1 **] today
   -- continue holding home Lisinopril, consider restarting tomorrow
   -- goal 1L negative today, with lasix later prn
   .
   #. HYPERLIPIDEMIA, h/o STEMI:
   -- cont home regimen of ASA, Lipitor
   -- increase Carvedilol to home dose of 25mg [**Hospital1 **] today
   .
   #. GERD: cont home omeprazole 40 mg QD
   .
   #. DIABETES:
   -- humalog SSI (decease to [**Hospital1 **] checks as pt is not requiring any
   insulin)
   .
   #. FEN:
   -- cont home MVI, B1, folic acid
   -- on tube feeds (replete with fiber at 70 cc/hr), free water flushes
   200 ml Q6 hours
   .
   #. ACCESS: PICC on right placed [**11-23**]
   .
   #. PPX: -- Lovenox for 6 months started mid-[**2202-11-2**], bowel
   regimen, home omeprazole
   .
   #. CODE: FULL
   .
   #. ICU consent: signed and in chart
   .
   #. DISPO: rehab screening currently, pt has a bed in [**Hospital1 630**] (family
   does not want patient going back to rehab)
